title: Virtual moneybox to teach kids to save
text:
Virtual moneybox to teach kids to save 
  12:58 p.m. 
The technology was developed by ASB in collaboration with Saatchi & Saatchi 
A new virtual moneybox launched today is aimed at teaching children to save in the digital age. 
The technology is designed to allow parents to swipe virtual money from the ASB mobile app into a physical elephant-shaped moneybox –modelled on the late Kashin the elephant and called 'Clever Kash' – for their child. 
The amount of money in the moneybox will then be displayed in the elephant's tummy, with elephant noises sounding every time the app is used. 
"Parents are telling us they're finding it challenging to teach their children about the value of money as they don't tend to use cash and coins for everyday purchases," says ASB's chief executive Barbara Chapman. 
"Today, children are more likely to see their children handing over a card to pay, and so may not appreciate how much things cost or see change calculated, as we do when paying in notes and coins." 
The technology was developed by ASB in collaboration with Saatchi & Saatchi over a period of 12 months. The bank says they developed three different designs for the moneybox with feedback from children favouring the elephant design.
